sn55.24:9.7: saddhamattaka is consistently used in a diminutive sense, “mere faith”, as contrasted with saddhamatta “a degree of faith”. The latter is sufficient for one to progress in the path (MN 22, SN 55.24), but with the former one just gets by (MN 65).
sn55.24:9.9: This is a striking image, and I can’t help wondering if there hasn’t been some confusion with “mahasala” ='the affluent', referring back to the gossips at the start of the sutta? On the other hand, at AN 8.44 a similar idiom clearly means trees, and the parallels for SN 55.24 at SA 936 and SA2 160 both say “tree”.
